Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Coupled Geochemical and Geobiological Characterization of Dissolved Matter Oxidation to Carbon Dioxide
Award.AbstractNarration:
Organic molecules dissolved in aquatic ecosystems represent the largest pool of organic matter transported through river networks and one of the most complex mixtures on Earth. The processing of these organic molecules by microorganisms resulting in their conversion to CO2 contributes to the large exchange of CO2 between the aquatic environment and the atmosphere with implications for global climate change. Despite the importance of this phenomenon, as much as 80% of the organic carbon susceptible to microbial metabolism remains unidentified. The goals of this study are to use recent advances in low through-put, ultra-high resolution analytical organic chemistry to identify and characterize the pool of biologically reactive molecules and to extend the ability of commonly used high through-put, low-resolution optical techniques to provide information about the temporal dynamics of these molecules in river networks. The outcomes of this research could advance the understanding of the link between the composition of organic molecules in a river network and the evasion of CO2 to the atmosphere, answering the question of what makes an organic molecule biodegradable. The researchers will work with educators who teach K-12 students in making processes that are invisible to the naked eye accessible and compelling as the educators develop curricula that depict the influence of molecular geochemistry and microbial geobiology to life on Earth.

The researchers hypothesize that: (1) biologically reactive but molecularly uncharacterized humic molecules account for the majority of dissolved organic matter that bacteria respire to CO2; (2) the constituents of colored or fluorescent dissolved organic matter can be associated with groups of individual molecular formulas through the use of advanced statistical analyses, including Spearman Rank and 2-D correlation analyses; and (3) dissolved organic matter molecules that are ubiquitous across distant watersheds span the biological reactivity spectrum, while molecules unique to a watershed are predominantly reactive and readily converted to CO2. The research will be performed in streams within 2 well characterized river basins, one in the temperate forests of Pennsylvania and one in the tropical evergreen forests of Costa Rica. Water samples will be collected under baseflow and storm flow conditions, across stream orders and seasons, and separated into biological reactivity classes using stream water-fed plug flow bioreactors. The samples will be molecularly characterized using Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometry as well as UV-visible absorbance and fluorescence spectra with excitation emission matrices. The successful completion of the research should advance the ability to use optical sensors to understand carbon flow through river networks and advance the understanding of the molecular nature of the dissolved organic matter that fuels the evasion of CO2 from streams and rivers to the atmosphere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microbial decomposition of dissolved organic matter (DOM) in freshwater systems is believed to contribute significantly to the flux of CO2 to the atmosphere, and represents a major potential driving force for global climate change. While the majority of compounds in freshwater DOM are known to be derived from soil and plant litter in watersheds, little is known regarding the chemical composition for the reactive fraction of DOM or that fraction that is readily decomposed to CO2.  A better understanding of the chemical composition of DOM may therefore give insight into the susceptibility a given molecular formula has to microbial decomposition. It was previously assumed that the fraction of DOM contributing the most to CO2 production were those easily assimilated by microbes, such as amino acids, carbohydrates, and organic acids. Recent studies show that this only accounts for 20% of microbial DOM uptake and the remaining 80% comes from a previously unidentified class of labile and semi-labile DOM that is much more complex in its chemistry than the simple molecules. In this work, freshwater samples collected from White Clay Creek in southeastern Pennsylvania, along with five streams at the Maritza Biological Station in Costa Rica were subjected to varying degrees of microbial degradation using a series of bioreactors with different residence times. Using ultrahigh resolution mass spectrometry along with 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, compounds present in DOM were identified categorized into labile, semi-labile, or recalcitrant fractions based on removal rates within the series of bioreactors. The mass spectrometry provides unique molecular formulas (due to the high resolving power) for compounds that are polar and have a molecular weight greater than 200 Daltons. 

The large sample set collected for this study resulted in a number of interesting findings. The first finding is that some small compounds thought to be extremely bioreactive (acetate) were observed to not be as biodegradable as was thought. We attribute this to the fact that these compounds may be associated with inorganic metals that retard or diminishes their bioavailability. This finding was made possible by the development and implementation of a non-invasive approach to NMR analysis of DOM used for the first time in such studies. 

A second finding was that the smallest streams sampled in the study contained the greatest number and diversity of formulas measured by mass spectrometry, with the number of nitrogen atom containing formulas increasing as stream size increased.  The incorporation of nitrogen is suggested to be the result of abiotic processes, because formulas do not match those expected from biologically produced compounds. 

A third finding was that once stream water was passed through the bioreactors, mass spectrometry indicated that ~30% of the initial formulas were still present, suggesting a large portion of DOM is resistant to microbial degradation.  New formulas produced during bioreactor treatments are largely nitrogen-containing and appear to be humic or soil-like materials. Samples taken during storm flow conditions show discernible differences when compared to normal base flow stream samples. 

Finally, canonical analysis of mass spectrometry data indicates base flow conditions are characterized by compounds enriched in oxidized lignin/tannin-like compounds as would be expected from plant materials subjected to intense biological reworking. Stormflow conditions showed that the DOM was more aliphatic, suggesting that plant wax or cuticle-like materials from vegetation were rapidly injected into the streams thus avoiding intensive microbial processing. Advanced statistical analysis (2D correlation) was also employed to track alterations to stream DOM as a function of bioreactor residence time based on mass spectrometry data. 2D correlation indicated formulas with intermediate and high molar H/C ratios decrease most substantially with increasing bioreactor time, consistent with these formulas being associated with molecules having the greatest propensity to be biodegraded.
